Nano iron oxide impregnated in chitosan bead as a highly
efficient sorbent for Cr(VI) removal from water
Jianbo Lua,b,*, Kai Xua, Jinmei Yanga, Yarong Haoa, Fang Chenga
aTianjin Key Laboratory of Aquatic Science and Technology, Tianjin Chengjian University, Tianjin 300384, China bSchool of Civil Engineering, Yantai University, Yantai 264005,China
*Corresponding author: jianbo98@126.com (Jianbo Lu) Tel: +86-22-23085117
Highlights  Nano Fe oxide impregnated in chitosan bead (NIOC) for Cr(VI) removal was
fabricated.
 NIOC synthesis was facile only using ferric salts and chitosan in alkaline
solutions.
 NIOC sorbent had high sorption capacity towards Cr(VI) (69.8 mg/g, pH 5).  Proposed mechanisms involved sorption, reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III) and
re-sorption.
 Saturated NIOC could be effectively regenerated by NaOH solution and reused.
Abstract Using Fe(III) salts and chitosan, nano iron oxide impregnated in chitosan bead (NIOC) was successfully synthesized for aqueous Cr(VI) detoxification via sol-gel technique without any additional crosslinking agent. NIOC characterization demonstrated that the iron in NIOC mainly existed as nano akaganeite (β-FeOOH) and complex with chitosan. Intraparticle diffusion was the major rate-limiting step. The maximal adsorption capacity was 69.8 mg/g (pH 5.0, 20 oC). Normal concentration of coexisting anions (SO4 2–, CO3 2–, SiO3 2–) showed insignificant competition, whereas PO4 3- suppressed the Cr(VI) sorption. Cr(VI)-loaded NIOC could be effectively regenerated by alkaline solutions. Column adsorption runs using granular NIOC could effectively treat about 1600 bed volumes of Cr(VI) solution (from 3.7 mg Cr/L in influent to < 0.5 mg Cr/L in effluent). The Cr(VI) removal mechanisms involved the direct sorption of Cr(VI) (electrostatic attraction and ligand exchange), reduction of Cr(VI) into Cr(III) and re-sorption of Cr(III) via chelation on NIOC surface. Chemical compounds studied in this article: Chitosan (PubChem CID: 21896651) Ferric chloride (PubChem CID: 24810) Potassium dichromate (PubChem CID: 24502) 1,5-Diphenylcarbazide (PubChem CID: 8789) Keywords: Nano iron oxide; Chitosan; Adsorption; Reduction; Hexavalent chromium; Sorbent bead

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Water contamination by chromium (Cr) has become a global environmental issue
(Bansal, Garg, Singh, & Garg, 2009). The Cr removal from aquatic environments is increasingly drawing people’s attention due to its potential hazard to human health. In aqueous solutions, chromium usually exists in two stable oxidation states, Cr(III) and Cr(VI). Cr(VI) has a greater health risk than Cr(III) due to its carcinogenic effect on
human body. By contrast, Cr(III) is environmentally benign and also an essential trace element in human body by regulating the insulin function(Nagarjuna, Challagulla, Ganesan, & Roy, 2017). In aqueous phase, Cr(III) is less soluble, and can be readily precipitated and separated as Cr(OH)3. The allowed Cr(VI) amount in industrial and civil wastewaters defined by the Europe Union is less than 0.2 mg /L(Di Natale, Erto, Lancia, & Musmarra, 2015). In China, the Cr(VI) maximum contaminant level (MCL) is also regulated stringently by the latest discharge standard. For instance, the Cr(VI) MCL in the effluent of industrial wastewater is 0.5 mg/L set by the Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Construction of China(GB/T 31962-2015). This brings great challenges for water treatment process to meet the stringent Cr(VI) MCL.
Various methods are developed to effectively remove Cr(VI) from water and
wastewater, including chemical precipitation, reduction, adsorption, and membrane filtration, etc. Amongst these treatment technologies, adsorption is widely employed to remove Cr(VI) due to its high efficiency, low costs and easy operation (Barrera-Díaz, Lugo-Lugo, & Bilyeu, 2012). Especially, exploitation of nanomaterial adsorbents has become of increasing interest to scientists and engineers owing to their large surface area and reaction sites(Khajeh, Laurent, & Dastafkan, 2013). Thereinto, nano iron oxides possess large natural abundance, low cost and high pHPZC (pH of point of zero charge), which makes them promising sorbents for anionic Cr(VI) removal from water. However, because of their small size, these nanoscale iron oxides are often difficult to separate from treated water, which hinders their recycling use (Kumari, Pittman Jr, & Mohan, 2015). To overcome this limitation, impregnation of iron oxide into a matrix such as polymer potentially provides a promising approach(Zhao et al., 2011). In particular, crosslinked polymeric hosts can provide controllable pore space for the impregnation of nano iron oxides, which facilitates the fabrication of granular sorbents via crosslink reaction. Furthermore, the appropriate choice of the polymer matrix with specific functional groups may enhance the adsorption performance of composite sorbent through synergistic effect. Among
studied polymers, chitosan is well known for its environmental friendliness and low cost, and is a good scavenger for metal ions owing to the amine (–NH2) and hydroxyl (–OH) functional groups in its structure(Vieira et al., 2014).
Nevertheless, chitosan also has some disadvantages when used in water
treatment. For instance, chitosan is soft and exhibits poor mechanical strength in aqueous solutions. It is anticipated that via impregnating of rigid iron oxides into chitosan matrix, a new organic/inorganic hybrid sorbent bead with excellent mechanical strength could be fabricated(Qi, Zhang, & Li, 2015). The hybrid sorbent can combine the good features of both iron oxide and chitosan, such as the excellent mechanical strength of iron oxides and encapsulation properties of chitosan matrix. Granular sorbent bead effectively solves the problem of difficult separation of nano iron oxides and is favorable for its application in fixed-bed columns or other flow-through systems.
Unfortunately, the reported preparation steps of iron oxide-chitosan hybrid
sorbents were complicated and costly. In order to facilitate the granulation of sorbents, crosslinking agents such as glutaraldehyde were applied in preparation, which had underlying hazards for human’s health(Boddu, Abburi, Talbott, Smith, & Haasch, 2008). Glutaraldehyde was reported to cause irritation of throat, eye, and skin when exposed repeatedly(Fürst & Banerjee, 2005). Additionally, in order to dissolve chitosan, acid (nitric acid, acetic acid and etc.) was often added in synthesis step, which was bound to increase the cost of sorbents(He, Bardelli, Gehin, Silvester, & Charlet, 2016). In order to prepare engineered sorbents, simple, feasible and economical synthesis method was usually more appreciated. Interestingly, it was also accepted that the Fe(III) salt hydrolysis can contribute to both acidity and iron oxide(Duan & Gregory, 2003). The hydrolysis of Fe3+ was a multi-step reaction and here simply expressed as follows.
Fe3++3H2O⇌Fe(OH)3+3H+ (1) Based on above considerations, in this study, a facile synthesis method of nano
iron oxide impregnated chitosan bead is adopted, which does not involve glutaraldehyde and acid. Under appropriate conditions, nano iron oxide was impregnated into chitosan matrix and a granular sorbent (NIOC) was fabricated only using Fe(III) salt and chitosan. Thus, the objectives of current study focused on: 1) characterization of NIOC morphology and structure, 2) examination of Cr(VI) adsorption performance, and 3) exploration of the Cr(VI) adsorption mechanism.

sections.heading: 2.1 Chemicals
sections.text:
Chitosan (CAS NO: 9012-76-4; deacetylation: 80–95%; viscosity: 50–800 mPa·s)
and other reagents used in current research were all purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Beijing Chemical Company) and were all of analytical grade unless specifically stated. The Cr(VI) stock solution was prepared in deionized water using potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7). Working solutions were diluted from the stock solution of Cr(VI) with deionized water before experiments.

sections.heading: 2.2 Synthesis of NIOC sorbent
sections.text:
NIOC was prepared using FeCl3·6H2O and chitosan. The synthesis sketch map of
the NIOC is illustrated in Fig.S1.The synthesis procedure was briefed as follows. Chitosan of 5 g was dissolved into 250 mL solution with 0.3 M FeCl3·6H2O under continuous stirring and heating for about 1 h to form a viscous gel. Then the dark red gel was dropped into NaOH solutions through a syringe and the beads with regular size were obtained. The above sorbent beads were washed with deionized water for several times until the elution solution approached neutral pH. Then the beads were dried in an oven at 50 °C for 24 h. The obtained sorbent materials were ground and sieved through 80 mesh for characterization and batch adsorption experiments.

sections.heading: 2.3 Characterization of NIOC sorbent
sections.text:
Scanning electron microscopic (SEM) image of the adsorbents was analyzed by
a field-emission electron source scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) (S4800, Hitachi Ltd., Japan). Meanwhile, the EDS spectra of the adsorbents before and after adsorption were also obtained by the above-mentioned scanning electron microscope. The XRD analysis was carried out on an X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation, at λ=1.5406 A (Ultima IV-185, RIGAKU, Japan). Samples were scanned from 4–90° 2θ at 40 mA and 40 kV with a scanning rate of 4°/min, and the step size was 0.02°. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of original chitosan and NIOC were collected on a transmission electron microscope using an accelerating voltage of 200 KV (Tecnai G2 F20, FEI, Netherland). Selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns were obtained with the smallest area aperture available (10 µm). Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FTIR, TENSOR 27, Bruker, Germany) was conducted in the wavenumber range of 400–4000 cm–1 with a resolution of 2 cm–1. The zeta potentials of the samples before and after Cr(VI) adsorption were measured by a zetasizer (Nano ZS, Malvern, UK) at different pH intervals. X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, Axis Ultra DLD, Japan) with an Al kα radiation was used to analyze the adsorbent before and after adsorption, and the results were regulated by C1s at a binding energy of 284.6 eV.

sections.heading: 2.4 Batch studies
sections.text:
To evaluate the adsorption capacities of NIOC, batch experiments including
sorption isotherms, sorption kinetics, effects of pH values and coexisting anions were carried out. Unless noted otherwise, experiments were conducted in 50 mL plastic tubes with 40 mL of various Cr(VI) concentrations using a dosage of 0.5 g/L NIOC. The tubes were placed on a shaker to obtain effective adsorption equilibrium. After samples were filtered with 0.45 μm fiber membranes, the concentrations of Cr(VI) in the filtrate were measured by a UV-Vis spectrophotometer at 540 nm (T6, Persee,
China) via a 1,5-diphenylcarbazide method(APHA,1998). If necessary, total Cr concentration was also determined using Atomic Absorption Spectrometer (TAS-986, Persee, China). The initial Cr(VI) concentration was 10 mg/L and the temperature was 20 oC unless specially stated. HCl and NaOH solutions were employed to adjust the pH values of solutions.
Sorption isotherms were conducted at different initial Cr(VI) concentrations (5–
60 mg/L). Sorption kinetics data were obtained at different time intervals (5–2160 min). The Cr(VI) solution volume was 500 mL and the initial Cr(VI) concentration was separately 10 mg/L and 20 mg/L. The effects of different aquatic conditions (coexisting anions, pH and ionic strength) on Cr(VI) sorption were also investigated. In the experiments on the influence of coexisting anions (CO3 2–, SO4 2–, SiO3 2–, PO4 3–), the concentrations of different anions were 0.5, 5 and 10 mM. The pH values of above experiments were maintained at 5±0.1 using HCl and NaOH solutions. As for the effects of solution pH and ionic strength, solution pH values ranged from 3 to 10, and the ionic strength (NaCl) was 0.001 M, 0.01 M and 0.1 M, respectively. All the batch data were the average of duplicate determinations.
Whether Cr(VI)-loaded NIOC could be regenerated effectively affected its
practicality in water treatments. Thus, regeneration and reusability of NIOC were investigated by batch tests for three consecutive adsorption-desorption cycles. In the adsorption process, NIOC (0.5 g/L) was added into the solution with 20 mg/L Cr(VI) and the solution pH was kept at 5±0.1. After stirred for 24 h at room temperature, the solution was filtrated and the Cr(VI) concentration in the filtrate was determined. The Cr(VI)-loaded adsorbent was separated for regeneration study. In regeneration process, alkaline solutions are often used as desorption solution. Thus, the Cr(VI)-loaded NIOC sorbent was put into 0.01 M NaOH solution and stirred for 12 h and then washed with deionized water until neutral pH was reached. The regenerated adsorbent was dried and used for next adsorption-desorption cycle.

sections.heading: 2.5 Column studies
sections.text: The fixed-bed column was made of plexiglass with an internal diameter of 16 mm and a bed height of 260 mm. The particle size of NIOC ranged from 1.4 to 2.0 mm. Column tests were operated at room temperature using upflow mode and input flow rate was controlled at 7 mL/min using a peristaltic pump, where corresponding empty bed contact time (EBCT) was 7.5 min. The upflow mode was chosen in order to increase solid-liquid contact time and avoid any channeling of the influent solution. The initial concentration of Cr(VI) was 3.7 mg/L and the solution pH was 5.0. After adsorption cycle, the exhausted NIOC was subjected to regeneration by using NaOH solution (0.5 M). At different time intervals, the effluent samples were collected and the Cr(VI) concentration was determined.

sections.heading: 3.1 Characterization of NIOC
sections.text:
The photo of NIOC sorbent is shown in Fig.1(a). The NIOC exhibited an uneven
and porous surface possibly hinting its good adsorbability towards aqueous contaminants. The SEM-EDS results of sorbent samples are shown in Fig.S2. The SEM image showed that the surface of the NIOC was relatively rough and showed the appearance of biopolymer agglomerates. Presumably, different species of iron could be impregnated into the net-like structure of chitosan gels formed during the fabrication step of the NIOC. The EDS graph displayed the existence of some representative elements, including C, N, O and Fe on the surface of NIOC samples. Obviously, the chitosan used in preparation procedure contained carbon chains and functional groups such as hydroxyl (–OH) and amino (–NH2) resulting in the occurrence of C, N and O in this adsorbent material. Further, after Cr(VI) reaction with NIOC, Cr peaks were evidently observed in the EDS spectrum hinting the Cr sorption on NIOC. Table S1 lists the C, N, O and Fe and Cr percentage on the surface
of original NIOC, which was 50%, 3.21%, 22.58%, 24.21%, 0%, respectively. After Cr(VI) adsorption, the Cr percentage in the NIOC sorbent samples increased up to 0.78%. Possibly due to the introduction of hexavalent chromium (mainly HCrO4 -), the proportion of O climbed to 30.71% after adsorption.
The XRD patterns of original chitosan and NIOC are shown in Fig.1(b). As for
the chitosan, a sharp peak around 2θ=10–23° was found likely due to the presence of hydrophilic groups. However, this peak disappeared in NIOC sorbent. It is speculated that Fe(III) might be chelated with the hydrophilic function groups on the backbone of chitosan such as amino group (–NH2)(Hernández et al., 2008). The XRD pattern of NIOC sample displayed four poor peaks situated at d-spacings of 3.33, 2.55, 1.64, 1.49 Å corresponding to the (310), (211), (620) and (112) lattice planes of akaganeite (β-FeOOH) (JCPDS No.34-1266), which generally hinted the poor crystallinity of NIOC. It has been demonstrated that in the preparation step of β-FeOOH by the hydrolysis of ferric salts, the chloride ion was indispensable (Schwermann &Cornell, 2000). This was in concert with our current study, in which ferric chloride was used as the ferric source. Moreover, the color of NIOC granular sample was brown that was consistent with the expected colors of iron in the form of akaganeite. The TEM images of original chitosan and NIOC provided further insight into their morphology and particle size. Original chitosan had a uniform surface with microporous structure (Fig.1(c)). Whereas, in NIOC images (Figs.1(d)–(e)), rod-like nanoparticles with a diameter of about 2 nm and length of about 10 nm were observed, indicating that the nano iron oxide was successfully impregnated inside the micropore of original chitosan. Fig.1(d) also showed that the nanoparticle had an interplanar spacing of about 2.477 Å, which corresponded to the (011) plane of β-FeOOH. SAED patterns of NIOC are shown in Fig.1(f). Four rings corresponded to the inter-planar distances (d) observed in XRD pattern, which were consistent with those of akaganeite (β-FeOOH). The SAED result was in general agreement with the XRD result.

sections.heading: 3.2 Sorption kinetics and modeling
sections.text:
In order to design an appropriate adsorption system, it is of vital importance to
investigate the sorption kinetics of Cr(VI). Further, the sorption equilibrium time on adsorbents was also determined by kinetics studies. The results of Cr(VI) sorption kinetics are shown in Fig.2(a). The Cr(VI) sorption on NIOC was initially very fast. As for 10 mg/L and 20 mg/L of Cr(VI), above 80% and 60% of uptake occurred at the first 30 min. Following that, it was the slow sorption process. The Cr(VI) sorption increased slowly and reached a plateau after about 300 min and 600 min, respectively, for 10 mg/L and 20 mg/L of Cr(VI).
To better describe the adsorption process, three commonly-used kinetics models
including pseudo-first order, pseudo-second order and Elovich models were adopted to fit sorption kinetics data. These three models were separately given as follows:
pseudo − first order model: 𝑞𝑡 = 𝑞𝑒(1 − 𝑒 −𝑘1𝑡) (2) pseudo − second order model: 𝑞𝑡 = 𝑞𝑒
2𝑘2𝑡 (1 + 𝑞𝑒𝑘2𝑡) ⁄ (3)
Elovich model: 𝑞𝑡 = ln (𝛼𝛽) 𝛽⁄ + 𝑙𝑛𝑡 𝛽⁄ (4)
where k1 (min –1) and k2 (g/(mg·min)) represent the pseudo-first order and pseudo-second order rate constants, respectively; qt (mg/g) and qe (mg/g) are separately the adsorption capacities at equilibrium and time t; α (mg/(g·min)) is the initial Cr(VI) adsorption rate, and β (g/mg) is the desorption constant. The obtained constants of three models are listed in Table S2.
It is obvious that according to the regression coefficients (R2), the fitting order
was as follows: the pseudo-second order model > the Elovich model > the pseudo-first order model. The pseudo-second order model described the kinetic data best (R2 > 0.99) indicating that chemisorption might play a dominant role in the sorption process(Qi et al., 2015). The k2 value was separately 7.09×10–3 g/(mg·min) and 1.02×10–3 g/(mg·min) for the initial concentrations of 10 mg/L and 20 mg/L. This indicates that the adsorption rate at low Cr(VI) concentration was much faster than that at high concentration as can be seen from the kinetics data (Fig.2(a)). It can
be concluded that the NIOC sorbent was more suitable for the sorption of low concentration Cr(VI).
Generally speaking, adsorption process can be separated into three consecutive
steps. The first step was the diffusion of the adsorbate to the external particle surface (boundary diffusion), and this stage was relatively rapid. The rate of the second step was moderate, which was dominated by intraparticle diffusion. At the third step, the adsorbate was adsorbed on the interior sites of the sorbent by a slow sorption rate, which might be attributed to the hindrance from the adsorbed molecules(Ren, Shao, & Zhang, 2012). To confirm the rate-limiting step of Cr(VI) adsorption onto NIOC, Weber-Morris intraparticle diffusion model was taken into consideration (Eq.(5)):
𝑞𝑡 = 𝑘𝑝𝑡 0.5 + 𝐶 (5)
where qt is the sorption amount (mg/g) at time t; kp is the intraparticle diffusion rate constant, C is the intercept (mg/g). The fitting plots of intraparticle diffusion model are shown in Fig.2(b).
If the plot of qt versus t 0.5 was a straight line and passed the origin, then the
intraparticle diffusion was the sole rate-controlling step. However, in the current study, the whole plot can be divided into three linear parts, corresponding to the three stages of the adsorption. The whole fitting plot was nonlinear and did not pass through the origin, indicating that the first step (boundary diffusion) controlled the adsorption to some extent(Cheung, Szeto, & McKay, 2007). The slopes of the first straight lines were greater than those of the second and third straight lines. It implied that the sorption rate of boundary diffusion process was relatively faster than the rate of intraparticle diffusion. It could be concluded that intraparticle diffusion was the major rate-limiting step. For the two Cr(VI) concentrations, the slopes of the third linear lines were both very low, which represented a slow adsorption stage due to the hindrance from adsorbed pollutants.

sections.heading: 3.3 Isotherms and thermodynamics analyses
sections.text:
The Cr(VI) adsorption isotherms on NIOC was investigated at pH 5.0. The
results as shown in Fig.2(c) demonstrate that at different temperatures (10 oC, 20 oC, 30 oC), NIOC had a high sorption performance for Cr(VI). The Cr(VI) removal efficiency were all above 90% when the equilibrium Cr(VI) concentration was 2.0 mg/L at three temperatures. When the equilibrium Cr(VI) concentration reached about 25 mg/L, the removal efficiency still remained about 50%. Above results further indicated that NIOC was favorable for the removal of low concentration Cr(VI), which was in line with the results of kinetics data.
The Langmuir and Freundlich isotherm model were further applied to simulate
the adsorption data at three temperatures. The Langmuir model was presented as:
𝑞𝑒 = 𝑞𝑚𝑎𝑥𝐾𝐿𝐶𝑒
(1 + 𝐾𝐿𝐶𝑒) ⁄ (6)
where qe (mg/g) is the amount of adsorption at equilibrium and Ce (mg/L) is the equilibrium Cr(VI) concentration in solution; qmax is the maximum amount of Cr(VI) adsorbed on NIOC; KL (L/mg) is the Langmuir constant. The Freundlich model was expressed as Eq.(7):
𝑞𝑒 = 𝐾𝐹(𝐶𝑒) 1/𝑛 (7)
where KF is a constant related to the adsorption capacity, and n is a constant about adsorption intensity. The obtained fitting curves of the two models are illustrated in Fig.2(c) and the fitting parameters are listed in Table 1.
Evidently, the correlation coefficients R2 values calculated from the Freundlich
model were all higher than those from the Langmuir model at three temperatures, suggesting that the Freundlich model described the adsorption process better than the Langmuir model. If adsorption process fitted the Langmuir model, it was generally thought that the monolayer coverage of adsorbate was formed over a homogeneous adsorbent surface and adsorbate did not react chemically with the adsorbent surface. In the current study, NIOC was a hybrid sorbent material containing different active species of Fe(III) and chitosan. As a result, NIOC could have a heterogeneous surface
and a multilayer coverage of adsorbate(Qi et al., 2015; Zimmermann, Mecabô, Fagundes, & Rodrigues, 2010).This accounted for the better fitting for the isotherms data using the Freundlich model. The n value in the Table 1 ranged from 2.26 to 2.73, which were all above 1, indicating that the Cr(VI) adsorption on NIOC was favorable(Albadarin et al., 2012).
Sorption capacity was one of the important parameters representing sorption
performance. From the isotherm data, the obtained maximum sorption capacity of Cr(VI) on NIOC was about 69.8 mg/g. Table 2 presents the comparison of sorption capacities of Cr(VI) on commonly used typical sorbents. The reported sorption amount of Cr(VI) on activated alumina, hematite, goethite, chitosan, activated carbon and MWCNTs was separately 7.44, 2.30, 1.96, 35.6, 46.9 and 2.84 mg/g, which were far less than that on NIOC. Compared to the metal oxides and chitosan, the NIOC sorbent in the current study had an appreciable sorption performance towards Cr(VI). Thus, the granular NIOC was a promising sorbent material and easy to pack into fixed-bed columns for the effective removal of Cr(VI) in water treatment process.
The thermodynamic parameters of adsorption process were further estimated,
which provided detailed information regarding the inherent energetic changes associated with adsorption. The thermodynamics parameters were calculated by Eq. (8).
𝑙𝑛𝐾𝑑 = −∆𝐻 𝑅𝑇⁄ + ∆𝑆 𝑅⁄ (8)
where Kd is the ratio of the adsorbed Cr(VI) amount to the equilibrium Cr(VI) concentration; ΔH (kJ/mol) is the enthalpy; ΔS (J/(mol·K)) is the entropy; R is the ideal gas content (8.314 J/(mol·K)); T is the reaction temperature in K. Based on Eq.(8), the plot of lnKd against T −1 is a straight line. The values of ΔH and ΔS could be calculated from the slope and intercept of Eq.(8).
The Gibbs free energy (ΔG, kJ/mol)) could be calculated by Eq.(9). ∆𝐺 = ∆𝐻 − 𝑇∆𝑆 (9) The fitting plot (lnKd versus T −1) is shown in Fig.2(d), and the obtained R2 value
was 0.946 indicating the goodness of fitting. The thermodynamic parameters of Cr(VI) adsorption on NIOC are listed in Table S3. The negative value of ΔG indicated that the Cr(VI) adsorption on NIOC was spontaneous and feasible in nature. The ΔH was negative suggesting that the Cr(VI) adsorption process was exothermal, and the lower temperature was propitious to the adsorption. The negative ΔS value hinted a decrease in randomness at the interface between the adsorbent and the solution during the adsorption(Albadarin et al., 2012).

sections.heading: 3.4 Effects of aquatic conditions
sections.text:
The effects of aquatic conditions including coexisting anions, pH and ionic
strength on Cr(VI) sorption were investigated as shown in Figs.3(a)–(b). Clearly, with the increment of solution pH from 3 to 10, the sorption amount of Cr(VI) decreased gradually regardless of ionic strength. On one hand, pH affected the species of Cr(VI) (Fig.S3). When pH < 5.9, the predominant form of Cr(VI) was HCrO4 –. At pH > 5.9, the main form of Cr(VI) shifted from HCrO4 – to CrO4 2– with increasing pH. On the other hand, the surface charge of NIOC varied with the pH values. From Fig.S4, the pHpzc (pH of point of zero charge) of NIOC was estimated to be about 7.5. Thus, when solution pH was below 7.5, the surface of NIOC was positively charged. The electrostatic attraction between NIOC and HCrO4 – could explain the high adsorption amount. As for Cr(VI)-loaded NIOC, the PZCs were shifted to lower pH value with increasing Cr(VI) concentration. Shifts in PZC with increasing Cr(VI) concentration were the characteristics of inner-sphere adsorption. The poor Cr(VI) sorption amount at a higher pH value could be attributed to the following two reasons: (1) with the increasing of pH, increasing OH– ions in solutions could compete intensely with CrO4 2– for adsorption sites; (2) at pH ＞ pHpzc, the NIOC surface charge became more negative with increasing pH and resulted in the increment of repulsive forces, which was also a plausible explanation for the decrease of Cr(VI) sorption. Furthermore, the concentrations of effluent Fe in the pH range of 3–10 was
determined to examine the stability of NIOC and the Fe concentrations were found to be all below 0.05 mg/L, which implied that the sorbent had a good stability. Fig.3(a) further shows that, the Cr(VI) adsorption on NIOC exhibited inconspicuous ionic strength dependence in the pH range of 3 to 10, which was likely indicative of inner-sphere adsorption mechanism for Cr(VI) on NIOC. This was in agreement with the mechanism inferred from above PZC shifts results(Goldberg & Johnston, 2001).
Fig.3(b) presents the competition effects of commonly co-present anions (CO3 2–,
SO4 2–, SiO3 2–, PO4 3– and etc.) in aquatic systems on Cr(VI) sorption. Clearly, with the increment of anion concentrations from 0 mM to 5 mM, the adsorption capacities decreased slightly by about 0.7%–1.3% for CO3 2–, SO4 2– and SiO3 2–. Whereas, when their concentrations reached 10 mM, there were significant competition effects on Cr(VI) adsorption. As for CO3 2–, SO4 2– and SiO3 2–, removal efficiencies of Cr(VI) decreased by 23.7%, 20.6% and 28.4% respectively. Nevertheless, the concentrations of these coexisting anions were normally less than 1 mM in aquatic environments (Stumm &Morgan, 2012), and their effects on Cr(VI) adsorption could be negligible.
By comparison, coexisting PO4 3– had a significant influence on Cr(VI) sorption
when its concentration ranged from 0.5 mM to 10 mM. When the concentration of PO4 3– was 0.5 mM, the adsorption amount decreased by 35.6% which was much more than those of the rest three anions at the same concentration. And the removal efficiency of Cr(VI) decreased by 59.8% when the concentration of PO4 3– reached 10 mM. Possibly, the structure of PO4 3– was similar to that of HCrO4 –, so PO4 3– would strongly compete for the adsorption sites with HCrO4 –.

sections.heading: 3.5 Desorption and reusability
sections.text:
Whether adsorbate can be effectively desorbed from saturated adsorbent and the
adsorbent can be used repeatedly is quite important in the engineering applications of adsorbents. In the current study, three successive sorption-regeneration cycles were conducted to assess the regeneration and reusability of NIOC, and the results are
shown in Fig.3(c). The original sorption amount of NIOC towards Cr(VI) was found to be 28.4 mg/g. After the first regeneration using 0.01 M NaOH solutions, sorption amount slightly decreased by 3.5%. For the second cycle, sorption capacity separately decreased by 9.2% compared to the original adsorption. After three cycles, more than 87% of original sorption amount was maintained. The results show that saturated NIOC sorbent can be effectively regenerated via NaOH solution treatment and used repeatedly. NIOC can become a promising candidate sorbent for Cr(VI) removal in water treatments.

sections.heading: 3.6 Column studies
sections.text:
Given the engineering practicability of sorbent, fixed-bed column studies were usually necessary to estimate the breakthrough time and corresponding bed volume numbers from breakthrough curve. The breakthrough curve for Cr(VI) sorption on granular NIOC is shown in Fig.3(d). In this curve, the number of bed volumes (BV) is defined as the volume of treated Cr(VI) stream divided by the volume of sorbent applied. It was found that, when the Cr(VI) MCL was set as 0.5 mg/L (GB/T 31962-2015), the breakthrough of the Cr(VI) was about 1600 bed volume and its corresponding breakthrough time was about 200 h. Column adsorption could easily bring down Cr(VI) concentration from 3.7 mg/L to below 0.5 mg/L and maintain it for a long time. The exhausted NIOC column was then subjected to in-situ regeneration using 0.5 M NaOH solution and desorption curve is illustrated in the inset of Fig.3(d). It was found that the adsorbed Cr(VI) could be effectively desorbed from NIOC. Maximum desorption took place within about 24 bed volumes, and the Cr(VI) concentration in desorption solution reached more than 600 mg/L. And then it reduced gradually to below 0.5 mg/L at 225 bed volumes. After desorption, the adsorption column was rinsed with tap water until the effluent pH was neutral. The regenerated NIOC column could be reused for the next cycle of adsorption– desorption. Above results further suggest that the granular NIOC sorbent can be used
to purify Cr(VI)-contaminated water. Because an adsorption column allows continuous operation, NIOC may become a promising and reliable sorbent for water treatments.

sections.heading: 3.7 Removal mechanisms of Cr(VI)
sections.text:
To gain the removal mechanisms of Cr(VI) on NIOC, spectroscopic methods
including FTIR and XPS were employed as shown in Figs.4(a)–(d). For NIOC, the broad band around 3200–3400 cm–1 was due to O–H and N–H stretching vibrations in the hybrid sorbent(Hernández et al., 2008). The band at 2857 cm–1 was assigned to the C-H stretching vibration of methyl groups (–CH3) and methylene groups (–CH2) in chitosan(Elwakeel & Guibal, 2015). For the chitosan spectrum, the band at 1598 cm–1 was assigned to the amino group (–NH2) (Yao et al., 2012) whereas the band was weakened and broadened in NIOC and Cr-loaded NIOC spectra, which could be attributed to the chelation of –NH2 with metal ions such as Fe(III). The C–O signals from the secondary alcohol groups appeared at 1027, 1089 and 1156 cm–1 (Hernández et al., 2008). However, the intensity of these bands showed a visible decrease, which could be ascribed to the chelation of Fe(III) with the secondary alcohol groups(Hernández et al., 2008). The band at 895 cm–1 corresponded to the Fe–OH bending vibration of akaganeite in this hybrid sorbent(Gotić & Musić, 2007). This result was consistent with aforementioned XRD analysis. After Cr(VI) adsorption, two new bands appeared at the wavenumber of 790 cm–1 and 936 cm–1 in Cr(VI)-loaded NIOC spectrum, which were attributed to the vibrations of Cr–O and Cr=O bonds(Deng & Bai, 2004). This meant the adsorption of some chromium species (Cr(III) or/and Cr(VI)) on NIOC sorbent. This also explained the increasing proportion of O after Cr(VI) adsorption (Table S1).
The XPS analysis of O 1s before and after Cr(VI) sorption were conducted as
shown in Figs.4(b)–(c). The percentages of Fe–OH (both in the oxide and complex) and Fe–O on NIOC were 63.32% and 36.68%, respectively. After adsorption, the
percentage of Fe–OH decreased to 61.47%, and the percentage of Fe–O increased to 38.53%. It can be inferred that at pH 5.0, the protonated NIOC surface could carry functional groups such as Fe–OH, Fe–OH2 + and NH3 +. Thus, the electrostatic attraction and ligand exchange of anionic Cr(VI) with protonated NIOC surface represented possible adsorption mechanisms. The relevant reactions can be written as Eqs.(10–12):
Electrostatic attraction: Fe–OH2 ++HCrO4 – → Fe–OH2 +----HCrO4 – (10)
NH3 ++HCrO4 – → NH3 +----HCrO4 – (11)
Ligand exchange: Fe–OH+HCrO4 – →Fe–HCrO4+OH – (12) The high resolution Cr 2p XPS spectrum was further analyzed (Fig.4(d)). The
binding energy of Cr 2p1/2 and Cr 2p3/2 appeared within the range of 580–590 and 573–580 eV, respectively. The Cr 2p3/2 band at 574.4 and 576.7 eV was separately attributed to the Cr(III) and Cr(VI) species on NIOC(Biesinger, Brown, Mycroft, Davidson, & McIntyre, 2004). It is speculated that partial Cr(VI) was chemically reduced to Cr(III) on the surface of NIOC.
The concentration variations of different Cr species including total chromium
(TCr), Cr(VI) and Cr(III) over contact time were also monitored during Cr(VI) removal using NIOC sorbent (Fig.5). With the increment of contact time, TCr concentration fell sharply at the first 30 min, and then it decreased slightly to reach a plateau. In contrast, Cr(VI) concentration showed a gradually decreasing trend and reached 1.0 mg/L at 1440 min. Whereas, the concentration of Cr(III) in the solution decreased initially and increased up to 2.3 mg/L at the end of the experiment. The initially rapid decrease of Cr(III) concentrations was likely indicated that the reduction reaction of Cr(VI) into Cr(III) occurred on the NIOC surface, and immediately the reduced Cr(III) was re-sorbed by the active sites on NIOC. However, the active sites of Cr(III) adsorption were rapidly saturated within about 30 min. Whereafter, the continuous reduction reaction of Cr(VI) into Cr(III) resulted in the increment of Cr(III) concentrations in solutions.
Acknowledgedly, Cr(VI) was a strong oxidizing agent especially in acid
solutions(Mandal, Sarkar, Bolan, Ok, & Naidu, 2017). As shown in Fig.S2, when solution pH was 5.0, there was a significant portion of HCrO4 – species (Cr2O7 2– coexists when Cr(VI) concentration exceeds 0.01 M)(Rojas et al., 2005), which could act as an oxidant in aqueous solution. As for the NIOC sorbent, the primary alcohol hydroxyl of chitosan could supply electrons for Cr(VI) reduction, resultly, hydroxyl group (–OH) was converted into carbonyl group (C=O) and Cr(VI) was simultaneously reduced to less soluble and less toxic Cr(III) species(Jung et al., 2013). Furthermore, chitosan was a well-known chelating agent. Thus, a part of reduced Cr(III) could interact with amino groups (–NH2) via chelation in NIOC sorbent. And the other chromium retained as the form of Cr(III) in solutions. Based on above discussion, the removal mechanisms of Cr(VI) on NIOC mainly involved adsorption (electrostatic attraction and ligand exchange), chemical reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III) and re-sorption of Cr(III) via chelation. These reactions could be expressed as follows.
Reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III): HCrO4 – →Cr(III) (13) Oxidation of R–CH2OH to R–CH=O: R–CH2OH→R–CH=O (14) Chelation of Cr(III) with –NH2: –NH2+Cr(III)→NH2–Cr(III) (15) Combining the above analyses, the schematic diagram of Cr(VI) removal is
depicted in Fig.6.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Nanoscale iron oxide was facilely impregnated in chitosan matrix only using
cheap Fe(III) salts and chitosan. As-prepared sorbent (NIOC) was applied to remove Cr(VI) from water. Characterization of XRD, TEM, SAED and FTIR demonstrated that the iron in NIOC mainly existed in the state of rod-like nano akaganeite (β-FeOOH) and complex with –OH and –NH2 of chitosan. Cr(VI) sorption rate on NIOC was very fast. Kinetic data were described best by the pseudo-second order
model indicating possible Cr(VI) chemisorption on NIOC. Intraparticle diffusion was the main rate-limiting step. Isotherm data could be better described by Freundlich model hinting the nature of heterogeneous sorption. The obtained maximum adsorption amount of Cr(VI) was 69.8 mg/g at pH 5.0. The Cr(VI)-loaded NIOC could be regenerated by NaOH solution and used repeatedly. Column adsorption runs could effectively treat about 1600 bed volumes of a synthetic Cr(VI) solution when the breakthrough point was set as 0.5 mg/L. Electrostatic attraction and ligand exchange between Cr(VI) and Fe–OH on NIOC were responsible for sorption mechanisms. Meanwhile, Cr(VI) was partially reduced to Cr(III) and re-sorbed on NIOC. This granular sorbent has the potential to be used in fixed-bed adsorption systems for Cr(VI) decontamination in water treatment.
